comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: That's a good definition of a corvette, however that particular definition is probably more true of World War 2 and post-WW2 era corvettes. At the time this was photograph was taken - let's say 1880 to 1900 perhaps - submarines were in use, but were rare. Ther fore the antisubmarine role of corvettes had not yet come into being. I think that Britannica online gives a useful and brief definition of old-time corvettes here: www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/138995/corvette There is no denying that this is quite a magnificent photo of a corvette, though.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/lifeasdaddy] Thanks for adding this definition. I've copied part of it here for everyone: "corvette, small, fast naval vessel ranking in size below a frigate. In the 18th and 19th centuries, corvettes were three-masted ships with square rigging similar to that of frigates and ships of the line, but they carried only about 20 guns on the top deck. Frequently serving as dispatchers among ships of a battle fleet, corvettes also escorted merchantmen and showed a nation’s flag in distant parts of the world." [http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/138995/corvette] AB

comment.author: 7892196@N02
comment._content: The late David Brown in one of his many tomes says the term corvette - in use in the Napoleonic era was adopted for small escorts such as the Flower class immediately prior to WWII. so I wonder whether this ship is a corvette or a screw frigate.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/7892196@N02] The plot thickens!
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/64403351@N08] Thanks for adding those links, I've replaced the photo with a larger version; it might provide some more clues.

AB

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content:
The location of this photo is a bit of a puzzle to me.   The improved hi-res version enables scrutiny of the background.
It doesn't appear to be Elizabeth Bay.  Nor Garden Island.   Nor Kirribilli.   Nor Balmain.  Nor Blues Point.   I can't figure out where it is.

comment.author: 66546790@N07
comment._content: The ship is under the Imperial German colours. This one is some of the German Carola class corvettes.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: It looks like Woolloomooloo Bay to me - Garden Island on the left. From Mrs Macquaries Chair. SMS 'Carola' visited Sydney often in the 1880s. Sister ships 'Olga' and 'Sophie' also visited with the 'Bismark' in June 1887. I wonder if this was the occasion? - SMH 10/06/1887 p.5 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13650624 . See also - AT+CJ 20/08/1887 p.26 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/71088385 It would take a Naval historian expert to pick between the ships. The 'Olga' looked like this -
